title: Surena (4th century)
text:
Surena (also spelled Suren) was a 4th-century <a href="Iranian%20peoples">Iranian</a> military officer active during the reign of the <a href="Sasanian%20Empire">Sasanian</a> king (<a href="shah">shah</a>) <a href="Shapur%20II">Shapur II</a> (). He played an important role in the denial of the <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman</a> invasion in 363 and the peace negotiations that followed.
Biography.
Surena was a member of the <a href="House%20of%20Suren">House of Suren</a>, one of the <a href="Seven%20Great%20Houses%20of%20Iran">Seven Great Houses of Iran</a>. The family, of <a href="Parthia">Parthia</a>n origin, had been active in Iranian politics since the <a href="Arsacid%20Empire">Arsacid Empire</a>, and held parts of <a href="Sakastan">Sakastan</a> as their personal <a href="fief">fief</a>dom. Surena was seemingly a powerful figure in the country, being described as "second in power after the king." He is first mentioned in 363, when he on April 24 ambushed a patrol force led by <a href="Hormizd%20%28Constantinople%29">Hormizd</a>, a brother of <a href="Shapur%20II">Shapur II</a>, who had entered the service of the Roman emperor <a href="Julian%20%28emperor%29">Julian</a> (). Hormizd only managed to escape due to the overflow of the <a href="Euphrates">Euphrates</a> which proved too much for Surena and his men. The following day after the Roman <a href="Siege%20of%20Pirisabora">sack of Pirisabora</a>, Surena ambushed three squadrons of the <a href="Roman%20cavalry">Roman cavalry</a>, killing some of them, including one of the <a href="Military%20tribune">tribunes</a>, and also captured an "<a href="Aquila%20%28Roman%29">aquila</a>".
At the <a href="Battle%20of%20Ctesiphon%20%28363%29">battle of Ctesiphon</a> on May 29, <a href="Pigranes">Pigranes</a>, Narseus and Surena were defeated by the Romans and as a result forced to retreat into the city walls. After the death of Julian the following month at <a href="battle%20of%20Samarra">Samarra</a>, Surena, who was at the time in <a href="Nor%20Shirakan">Nor Shirakan</a>, was sent with another nobleman to negotiate peace with the Romans. Upon arriving at the Roman camp, they were greeted by the newly declared emperor <a href="Jovian%20%28emperor%29">Jovian</a> (), who made <a href="Flavius%20Arinthaeus">Flavius Arinthaeus</a> his mediator for the peace agreement between the two parties. The treaty was called an "ignobili decreto" ("shameful treaty") by Romans, who had to concede eastern <a href="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Armenia%20%28antiquity%29">Armenia</a>, and the surrounding regions, counting fifteen castles and the important city of <a href="Nusaybin">Nisibis</a>, which had its Christian population moved to Roman soil.
